prompt: Write a poem about name badge in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Title: The Badge of Babel

'Twas brillig, and the slithy tags
Did gyrate, and roundabout:
All flimsy were the borogoves,
And the placards out of rout.

“Beware the Badge of Babel, son!
The jaws that bite, their clutches that snatch!
Beware the Jubjub card, and shun
The frumious Nametag-Snatch!”

He took his vorpal pen in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So clambered he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Badge of Babel, with eyes of flame,
Came sniffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal pen went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

“Hast thou slain the Badge of Babel?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy tags
Did gyrate, and roundabout:
All flimsy were the borogoves,
And the placards out of rout.
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on bittersweet victory in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Bittersweet Triumph

'Twas twilled and the timorous tykes
Did gyre and gallumph in the glade;
All flimsy were the flickering flames,
And the scintillating sneers they made.

"Beware the Vict'r =", my song! The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Jub jub beast, and shun
The frumious Bandersnatch!"

He took his vorpal sword in hand:
Long time the manxome foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Vict'r =, with eyes of flame,
Came galloping through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"Has thou slain the Vict'r =? Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas twilled and the timorous tykes
Did gyre and gallumph in the glade;
All flimsy were the flickering flames,
And the scintillating sneers they made.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about a promise kept in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Vow of the Vorpal Knight

Beware the Jabberwock, my son!
The Vorpal Knight his promise done.
On that mome rath, so long ago,
He vowed to slay the beastly foe.

Long time the manxome foe did lurk,
In Tulgey Wood, that shrouded murk.
The Vorpal Sword, so sharp and bright,
Did cleave the snicker-snack of night.

And hast thou slain the Jabberwock?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble in the groves;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
The mome raths outgrabe.

The Vorpal Knight, his promise kept,
In slumber deep, he lies, adept.
The Jabberwocky's head, aloft,
A testament to valor oft.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about paperclip chain in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Title: The Dance of the Twisty Clips

'Twas darp, and the silvy wreaths
Did gyle and gimble in the breeze;
All tyrl were the payer caps,
And the clumorous cleeves.

Beware the Twister-Crit, my son!
The jaws that bite, the bends that clutch!
Beware the Jubjub coil, and shun
The frumious Chain-Bandelette!

He took his vorpal clip in hand:
Long time the clustorous foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Twister-Crit, with eyes of flame,
Came sniffling through the silven wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal clip went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"Has thou slain the Twister-Crit?
Come to my arms, my shunar boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas darp, and the silvy wreaths
Did gyle and gimble in the breeze;
All tyrl were the payer caps,
And the clumorous cleeves.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on control theory in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Control Theorist's Jabberwock

'Twas brillig in the system’s fray,
The loops did gyrate, modeling all day;
Beware the Feedback, my son!
The teeth that bite, the gain that stings,
Beware the Instability, and shun
The frabjous Non-linearity!

He took his Laplace sword in hand,
Long sought the Transfer Function he’d planned;
Then rested he by a closed-loop tree,
And as in calculation thought he’d swoon.

The Feedback wiffled through mathy-toves,
Parameters all aflutter in the groves!
The Eigenvalues snickered at the sight,
The Nyquist plot, he drew with all his might.

But hast! Oh hast! The CLOCK struck twelve.
The panting beast emerged – the Instability to quell!
One, two! One, two! The sword went snicker-snack!
He split the beast, and the system’s prospects grew back.

“Hast thou silenced the Feedback beast?
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.
Control theory – the life, e’en death of fear,
A wonderstruck boy.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about error correction in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Beware the Flummoxed Glitch, my friend!
Its eyes alight with malice grand,
And shambling gait a strange sight to behold.
It drifts through lines of garbled dread,
And devours data without brevity.
My sword of ones, my shield of parity!

A task most dire, that must not whiff nor stray!
Embark we must, on this day, this fray!

To seek the Glitch’s source of birth,
Through tangled code and dusty devices’ mirth.
The squiggle-squaggled lines of jumbled mess,
Like tendrils of some primordial beast.

The Glitch’s eyes, they squint and gleam,
Its malice like a rusted dream.
And with a flutter, it unfurled,
A gaping maw, to swallow the world.

Oh, clash! Oh, clang! Oh, furious fight!
My sword of ones, it shines so bright!
For every error, each cursed bit,
Shall meet its doom, each flaw of grit.

The mighty strike! The error’s bane!
A chasm rents the dreadful strain.
And as the dust of primeval fear,
Settles down, the code rings clear.

The Flummoxed Glitch, its end has come,
The errors swept, undone and numb.
Ah, error correction, true and bold,
A story that shall long be told.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about evening breeze in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
'Twas dusk, and in the twilight air,
The Zephyr's whisper did declare,
Beware the evening's breath, beware!
Its fleeting touch, so soft and fair.

Its tendrils danced and twirled with glee,
And sang a song of mystery,
As shadows crept through silent trees,
The evening breeze it laughed with ease.

“Beware the Zephyr's wild embrace,
Which lulls you into gentle chase,
Through dreams and phantasms, you'll reside,
While the moon looks on with pride.”

The crickets joined the serenade,
And flickered in the twilight's shade,
A symphony of night began,
Accompanied by the zephyr's plan.

And as the stars made quite a din,
The whispering wind let out a grin,
The evening breath, it lulled them all,
And bid the creatures, “Heed my call.”

“Beware the evening's breath,” it sighed,
“You cannot hide, don't even try,
For in my reach, you'll dance and fly,
Until the dawn does break the sky.”
label: low

prompt: Compose a poem on zebra crossing in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Twas brillig on the asphalt strip,
And the zebra markings did equip,
All pedestrians with stripes of white,
Providing safe passage through the night.

Beware the Humgriffin, my dear friend!
The jaywalker's end is near, he'll send,
With blaring horns and flashing lights,
A warning to all who'd brave the nights.

He took his steadfast sneidel blade in hand,
Long time the driverwood foe he'd tanned,
So rested he by the tuffet tree,
And waited for a chance to cross free.

And, as in urban myth thought he,
The Humgriffin, with eyes of red he’d see,
Came roaring down the lane so fast,
Our hero thought he'd breathe his last.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The sneidel blade went snicker-snack!
He passed the crossing, safe intact,
And hastened to the other side back-to-back.

“Huzzah! I’ve slain the beast,” he cried,
As he admired his cunning stride.
And the stripes glowed brightly in the night,
Guiding travelers to safety with their light.

'Twas brillig on the asphalt strip,
And the zebra markings did equip,
All pedestrians with stripes of white,
Providing safe passage through the night.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about moving day in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Title: Shifting Shanty

'Twas morn of moving, fraught with woe and worry,
As boxes piled like hills, in stacks so hurried.
Through cardboard canyons, tape guns hissed and spat there,
The growling truck arrived, that mighty, metal martyr.

"Beware the fragile vase, my son, take care!
The lustre's shiny teeth, a cracked rim’s nightmare!"
He loaded up his gear, his order bid with grace,
And stood awhile, in thought, that boxes stared down face.

And, as in dreamlike thoughts, he pictured his new home,
So beautiful and bright, his happiness might roam.
Each room to neatly fill, with treasures old and new,
The snickersnack of packing done, his face lit up like June.

"O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
'Til final piece in truck, and locked away.
Did galumphing movers, race to heav'n by noon.
So settled in his mansion, his new life started soon.
label: low

prompt: Write a poem about burnt toast in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
In the Land of Charred Crustation

'Twas dawn, and the famished diner
Did fumble and thrumble in haste
All whitesky were the morning clouds,
And the nectarines out of place.

"Beware the Singed Slice, my lad!
The charcoal that bites, the crunch that maims!
Beware the Fake Call, and shun
The Smoky Toaster's wicked games!"

He took his knife in hand:
Long time the marred minx he sought—
So rested he by the toaster's side,
And watched it gleam, as he thought.

And, as in grumbly thought he stood,
The Singed Slice, with eyes of glee,
Came whiffling through the breakfast air,
And burnt his bread to a charred degree!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal knife went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head,
He re-toasted the burnt-to-black.

"Has thou slain the Singed Slice?
Come to my arms, my toastful boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas dawn, and the famished diner
Did gyre and gimble in the house;
All whitesky were the morning clouds,
And the nectarines out of place.
label: high
